awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is to minimize the risk of pressure ulcer formation in wheelchair users. In addition, this project will reduce the labor and cost associated with treating and preventing ulcers. Pressure ulcers are serious injuries that afflict those who are may already be suffering from other ailments such as paralysis and diabetes. They are often overlooked until it is too late, posing serious morbidity and mortality risk. Pressure ulcer prevention is a continuous job, and treatment of established ulcers is costly. Caretakers must constantly check, adjust, and turn at-risk wheelchair bound patients for the duration of the day. This is even more problematic with the nationwide staffing shortage in nursing homes. The most effective available cushions are cost prohibitive for most at-risk individuals and care facilities. Moreover, cushions that are widely used are prone to breaking, resulting in reoccurring costs and the need to reestablish constant care. Aside from the facilities and individuals who are affected, insurance companies in the US spend over $11 billion in treatment of ulcers every year and ulcers are the 2nd largest cause of medical malpractice lawsuits in the US.

This I-Corps project will develop a new wheelchair cushion that can minimize pressure ulcer onset. Prolonged sitting can lead to extreme discomfort, the breakdown of skin tissue, and the development of pressure ulcers. Strategies to mitigate this issue are based primarily on the principles of immersion and offloading. Immersion is the process of distributing interfacial pressure evenly across a surface. This is normally achieved with a foam or air cushion. Offloading is the process of suspending a specific region of the body in the air to remove and or redistribute pressure. To date, traditional strategies are ineffective in managing pressure ulcers. Immersion techniques can only reduce pressure magnitudes. Offloading cushions result in increased pressure and risk of pressure ulcer formation at support sites. This project develops a cushion that utilizes targeted offloading of high-risk areas to remove pressure alongside cyclic alternating pressure to prevent prolonged tissue deformation in non-offloaded sites. Furthermore, the rechargeable battery powered cushion is compact and quiet, so it does not interfere with a user's daily life.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The NSF’s I-Corps program has helped our team recognize, refine, and reach potential customers. Prior to the first I-Corps cohort, we expected the device could be sold to hospitals. However, through gaining insight from the I-Corps course, our customers changed from hospitals, to physicians, physical therapists, and occupational therapists. After talking to many of these individuals in hospitals and conferences San Francisco, CA, New York City, NY, Boston, MA, La Crosse, WI, Wichita, KS, Washington, D.C., and Columbus, OH, the target customer was altered to nursing home administrators, directors of nursing, and physical therapists in long-term care facilities.  Since our device is an active pressure cushion to alleviate and prevent pressure ulcer formation in wheelchair bound patients, we hypothesized that our device would be more applicable to long-term care facilities rather than high turnover short-term care facilities such as a hospitals. This hypothesis was confirmed in our subsequent travels after the on-site course. Residents in nursing homes have can have extended stays lasting months and years, with pressure ulcer occurrences being a top three concern for the nursing homes that we visited. Through interviews, we discovered that a number of nursing home staff desired a safe, portable, cordless, automated wheelchair cushion to prevent pressure ulcers.

Through customer discovery, we further discovered that nursing directors are more clinical than administrators. As such, it was paramount for us to recognize nursing directors as influencers; capable of leveraging the administrator purchasers. This was a key outcome from interviews. Moreover, it was clear after just a few nursing home facility interviews that administrators rely heavily on the directors of nursing to make decisions. The directors of nursing have contact with patients and nursing staff, while administrators rarely have first hand knowledge of patient care and treatment. However, administrators are directly responsible for pressure ulcer incidence rates at their facility. If these rates are too high, then there can be major repercussions. Another key outcome we learned that relates to the motivation to minimize pressure ulcers was that when pressure ulcer incidence rates are high, it notably impacts funding and reimbursement costs from insurance companies.  Low incidence rates result in larger refunds to the facility.

Care facilities are rated on a 5 star scale, with 5 being the best. The highest rated nursing homes receive more money, and are able to charge more for their services.  In contrast lower scoring nursing homes receive less money and seek ways to reduce pressure ulcer incidence rates. This knowledge ultimately impacted our reason to make a “go” decision. The course enabled our team to speak with over 100 nursing home executives, with nearly 95% of them highlighting pressure injuries were a top three problem and wanting a better solution than nurses moving the patient on a regular/hourly basis. A device capable of preventing pressure injuries would result in higher ratings, increased revenue for the nursing home, and reduced hands-on nursing time that is currently required to prevent pressure ulcers, freeing up nursing workloads to concentrate on other vital tasks.
